DOC.HEAD: China Blocking Meeting on Romania to Prevent Comparisons, Diplomats Say
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: China is blocking Security Council debate on the revolt in Romania because it fears comparisons with Beijing's own violent encounter with pro-democracy protests, diplomats said Tuesday. The Security Council put off discussion on Romania on Tuesday because of resistance by China, the diplomats said, speaking on condition of anonymity. A U.N. spokesman said only that the Romanian question, which had been placed on the agenda, had not been taken up. There was no comment from Chinese diplomats. Weeks of pro-democracy protests in China earlier this year were crushed by troops in Beijing. China says about 300 people died, 200 of them civilians. Witnesses and Western security sources say the toll may range from 500 to 3,000. In Romania, the new revolutionary government says more than 12,000 people were believed slain during a week of protests against the rule of ousted leader Nicolae Ceausescu, who ordered troops to shoot demonstrators. Mass graves were found in the western city of Timisoara. U.N. diplomats said China government wants to avoid any comparison with Romania. China has reacted sharply to international criticism to its crackdown. U.N. diplomats familiar with council proceedings said China, with the support of some developing nations, argued that the situation in Romania was strictly an internal affair and the international community should not become involved. Other diplomats argued, however, that the instability in Romania threatens Europe, and that maintaining international peace and stability is a legitimate concern of the 15-nation Security Council. Austria, Hungary, West Germany and Italy last week requested that the issue a statement about the crisis in Romania. They suggested the council could deplore the violence among the demonstrators, army and security forces and call for an orderly transition to democracy. China, however, refused Saturday to permit Security Council President Enrique Penalosa of Colombia to read an informal statement of concern to reporters. China is one of the five permanent council members with veto power and can block a statement. A council statement requires a concensus. The five permanent members are the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union.
